sentence:
This dataset provides a rare and valuable source of information about changes in population trends and area use by Southern Ocean phocids in a climate change hot spot.Methods
Survey methods
All data were collected at Cape Shirreff (62.47° S, 60.77°W) on the north shore of Livingston Island (Fig. 1).
However, censuses occasionally spanned two or three days due to extenuating circumstances (e.g., weather; Fig. 2).

Open in a new tab
Maps of the study site and the surrounding region: the South Shetland Islands and Cape Shirreff (a,b), and regular CS-PHOC survey locations as thick lines along the coast, shaded dark purple for the core census locations and aquamarine for Punta San Telmo (c).Fig. 2.

These core census locations span the vast majority of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff (Fig. 1), thereby ensuring that CS-PHOC data are both consistent and representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons.Data cleaning and aggregation
Data records were compiled from historical documents, field notebooks, Excel files, and a SQL Server database.

These aggregated core census location counts, along with counts for one other location (Punta San Telmo, described in “Data Records” below; Fig. 1), make up the published CS-PHOC dataset.Data publication
The CS-PHOC dataset described in this manuscript has been made Darwin Core compliant, and published as open data accessible via the SCAR Antarctic Biodiversity Portal (www.biodiversity.aq).

While implementing haul-out corrections is thereby currently impractical, CS-PHOC surveys were typically conducted in the middle of the day (between 1000 and 1500 local time) to maximize sighting probabilities for all species (Fig. 3).
Examples of possible ways to visualize and explore these data for the full timeseries are shown in Fig. 4.

Methods
Survey methods
All data were collected at Cape Shirreff (62.47° S, 60.77°W) on the north shore of Livingston Island (Fig. 1).
However, censuses occasionally spanned two or three days due to extenuating circumstances (e.g., weather; Fig. 2).

These core census locations span the vast majority of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff (Fig. 1), thereby ensuring that CS-PHOC data are both consistent and representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons.Data cleaning and aggregation
Data records were compiled from historical documents, field notebooks, Excel files, and a SQL Server database.

These aggregated core census location counts, along with counts for one other location (Punta San Telmo, described in “Data Records” below; Fig. 1), make up the published CS-PHOC dataset.Data publication
The CS-PHOC dataset described in this manuscript has been made Darwin Core compliant, and published as open data accessible via the SCAR Antarctic Biodiversity Portal (www.biodiversity.aq).

Survey methods
All data were collected at Cape Shirreff (62.47° S, 60.77°W) on the north shore of Livingston Island (Fig. 1).
However, censuses occasionally spanned two or three days due to extenuating circumstances (e.g., weather; Fig. 2).

Open in a new tab
Maps of the study site and the surrounding region: the South Shetland Islands and Cape Shirreff (a,b), and regular CS-PHOC survey locations as thick lines along the coast, shaded dark purple for the core census locations and aquamarine for Punta San Telmo (c).Fig. 2.

These core census locations span the vast majority of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff (Fig. 1), thereby ensuring that CS-PHOC data are both consistent and representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons.
All data were collected at Cape Shirreff (62.47° S, 60.77°W) on the north shore of Livingston Island (Fig. 1).
However, censuses occasionally spanned two or three days due to extenuating circumstances (e.g., weather; Fig. 2).

These core census locations span the vast majority of phocid haul-out locations at Cape Shirreff (Fig. 1), thereby ensuring that CS-PHOC data are both consistent and representative of phocid haul-out at Cape Shirreff across all censuses and seasons.
These aggregated core census location counts, along with counts for one other location (Punta San Telmo, described in “Data Records” below; Fig. 1), make up the published CS-PHOC dataset.
These aggregated core census location counts, along with counts for one other location (Punta San Telmo, described in “Data Records” below; Fig. 1), make up the published CS-PHOC dataset.

While implementing haul-out corrections is thereby currently impractical, CS-PHOC surveys were typically conducted in the middle of the day (between 1000 and 1500 local time) to maximize sighting probabilities for all species (Fig. 3).
Examples of possible ways to visualize and explore these data for the full timeseries are shown in Fig. 4.

While implementing haul-out corrections is thereby currently impractical, CS-PHOC surveys were typically conducted in the middle of the day (between 1000 and 1500 local time) to maximize sighting probabilities for all species (Fig. 3).
Examples of possible ways to visualize and explore these data for the full timeseries are shown in Fig. 4.
